SubTopics: Divide up to four-digit dividends by one-digit divisors with answers written as whole-number quotients and remainders.
Content: Divide: 7,218 ÷ 4

Key.Rationale: Does not do any subtraction, just divides 4 into each value.
Adds 4 and 1 instead of multiplying in the first step.
4 does not go into 1 in the tens place, so the student brings down the next place value and then divides.

SubTopics: Solve word problems involving multiplication of a whole number by a fraction (denominators limited to 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, 12, and 100).
Content: Chantel made a quilt using fabric squares that measured 3/4 foot on each side. She used 6 squares to make the length of the quilt. What is the length, in feet, of Chantel's quilt?

Key.Rationale: Multiplies 6 x 4, then 6 x 3 OR 6 x 3, then 6 x 4 (both derive 24/18).
Adds the values instead of multiplying.
Cross multiplies 6 x 4, then 1 x 3 and divides.

SubTopics: Add two fractions with respective denominators 10 and 100.

Key.Rationale: Converts 3/10 to 30/100, then adds numerators and denominators.

SubTopics: Demonstrate an understanding that in a multi-digit whole number (through 1,000,000), a digit in one place represents ten times what it represents in the place to its right.
Content: A restaurant served 6,352 meals during one month. Which statement correctly compares the value of the digit 6 in the number of meals served with the value of the digit 3 in the number of meals served?

A.Choice: The value of the digit 6 is 2 times the value of the digit 3.

B.Choice: The value of the digit 6 is 3 times the value of the digit 3.

C.Choice: The value of the digit 6 is 20 times the value of the digit 3.

D.Choice: The value of the digit 6 is 30 times the value of the digit 3.

SubTopics: Round multi-digit whole numbers (through 1,000,000) to any place.
Content: Mr. Coffman saw this ad for a used car in the newspaper.
problems/PA15G4M/media/5a.jpg
What is the greatest number of miles that the car could have been driven?

Key.Rationale: Least number of miles that rounds to 126,500.
Greatest number of miles under 126,500 that rounds to 126,500.
Least number of miles that rounds to 126,600.

SubTopics: Read and write whole numbers in expanded, standard, and word form through 1,000,000.
Compare two multi-digit numbers through 1,000,000 based on meanings of the digits in each place, using >, =, and < symbols.
Content: The populations of two towns are listed below.
Springfield: three hundred four thousand, twenty
Greenville: three hundred forty thousand, two
Which inequality correctly compares the two populations?

Key.Rationale: Does not correctly convert from word form to number form but compares the numbers correctly.
Converts from word form to number form correctly but does not correctly compare the numbers.
Does not correctly convert from word form to number form and does not correctly compare the numbers.

SubTopics: Read and write whole numbers in expanded, standard, and word form through 1,000,000.
Round multi-digit whole numbers (through 1,000,000) to any place.
Content: When rounded to the nearest ten thousand, Jake's high score on a video game is 170,000 points. Which could be Jake's actual high score?

Key.Rationale: Thinks this represents 167,350 instead of 16,735 and rounds correctly.

B.Choice: one hundred seventeen thousand, two hundred forty-one

C.Choice: one hundred sixty-two thousand, nine hundred ninety-nine

Key.Rationale: Makes a rounding error, thinking this rounds up because of the 999.

D.Choice: one hundred seventy-three thousand, nine hundred twenty-two

SubTopics: Add and subtract multi-digit whole numbers (limit sums and subtrahends up to and including 1,000,000).
Content: Graham practiced piano for 135 minutes this morning. He practiced for 65 more minutes this afternoon. Altogether, Graham practiced 10 times longer today than he practiced yesterday. How many minutes did Graham practice piano yesterday?

SubTopics: Add and subtract multi-digit whole numbers (limit sums and subtrahends up to and including 1,000,000).
Content: Mt. Etna is a volcano that measures 10,925 feet above sea level at its highest point. This is 11,664 feet less than the height of the world's highest volcano. What is the height, in feet, of the world's highest volcano?

Key.Rationale: Adds from left to right with regrouping (from the hundreds place to the tens place).
Subtracts in the ones place instead of adding, adds the remaining values.

SubTopics: Add and subtract multi-digit whole numbers (limit sums and subtrahends up to and including 1,000,000).
Round multi-digit whole numbers (through 1,000,000) to any place.
Content: The number of houses in each of three cities is shown below.

:box:• City 1 has 49,508 houses.

• City 2 has 650,279 houses.

• City 3 has 124,908 houses.
What is the total number of houses in all three cities rounded to the nearest thousand?

Key.Rationale: Rounds each number down to thousands and then adds.
Adds 3 numbers and then rounds down to thousands.

SubTopics: Multiply a whole number of up to four digits by a one-digit whole number, and multiply two two-digit numbers, using strategies based on place value and the properties of operations. Illustrate and explain the calculation by using equations, rectangular arrays, and/or area models.
Add and subtract multi-digit whole numbers (limit sums and subtrahends up to and including 1,000,000).
Content: Ruth and Mari sold fruit baskets for a school fundraiser. Ruth sold 42 fruit baskets. Mari sold twice as many fruit baskets as Ruth. They sold each fruit basket for $9. What is the total amount of money Ruth and Mari made selling fruit baskets?

SubTopics: Compare two fractions with different numerators and different denominators (denominators limited to 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, 12, and 100) using the symbols >, =, or < and justify the conclusions.
Content: Jason has a red pail and a blue pail that are the same size. The red pail is 3/5 full with water. The blue pail is 9/10 full with water. Which statement best explains why the blue pail has more water in it?

A.Choice: The numerator 9 is greater than the numerator 3.

B.Choice: The denominator 10 is greater than the denominator 5.

C.Choice: The fraction 3/5 is equal to 6/10, and 6/10 is less than 9/10.

D.Choice: The difference between the numerator and the denominator in 9/10 is less than it is in 3/5.

Key.Rationale: True only for fractions that have a common denominator and are less than or equal to 1.

SubTopics: Decompose a fraction or a mixed number into a sum of fractions with the same denominator (denominators limited to 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, 12, and 100), recording the decomposition by an equation. Justify decompositions (e.g., by using a visual fraction model).
Content: Kim's family had 1 1/4 apple pies remaining after a party. Each of the 6 people in Kim's family ate apple pie until all the apple pie was gone. Which expression could show the amount of apple pie each of the 6 people in Kim's family ate?

Key.Rationale: Does not account for all 6 people in Kim's family.
Does not add the fractions correctly.

SubTopics: Add and subtract mixed numbers with a common denominator (denominators limited to 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, 12, and 100; no regrouping with subtraction; fractions do not need to be simplified; and no improper fractions as the final answers).
Content: To make a repair, Jane needs a piece of wood that is 7 1/8 inches long. She has a piece of wood that is 12 5/8 inches long. How many inches of wood needs to be cut off so she has exactly 7 1/8 inches remaining?

SubTopics: Solve word problems involving addition and subtraction of fractions referring to the same whole and having like denominators, e.g., by using visual fraction models and equations to represent the problem.
Content: In Mr. Thom's marble collection, 5/12 of the marbles are glass and 3/12 of the marbles are steel. What fraction of the marbles in Mr. Thom's marble collection are either glass or steel?

SubTopics: Solve word problems involving multiplication of a whole number by a fraction (denominators limited to 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, 12, and 100).
Use decimal notation for fractions with denominators 10 or 100.
Content: A fruit drink is made from orange juice and pineapple juice. Orange juice makes up 7/10 of the fruit drink. What is the amount of orange juice in 8 gallons of the fruit drink?

SubTopics: Add two fractions with respective denominators 10 and 100.
Use decimal notation for fractions with denominators 10 or 100.
Content: On Jenny's farm 48/100 of the trees are pine trees and 3/10 of the trees are birch trees. What decimal number is equal to the fraction of the trees on Jenny's farm that are either pine trees or birch trees?

Key.Rationale: Incorrect sum of 51/100 and incorrect placement of decimal point.
Correct sum of 78/100 but incorrect placement of decimal point.
Incorrect sum of 51/100 but correct placement of decimal point.

SubTopics: Use decimal notation for fractions with denominators 10 or 100.
Add two fractions with respective denominators 10 and 100.

Add and subtract mixed numbers with a common denominator (denominators limited to 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, 12, and 100; no regrouping with subtraction; fractions do not need to be simplified; and no improper fractions as the final answers).
Content: Ramon bought 2.03 pounds of grapes last week. He bought 1.1 pounds of grapes this week. Which number sentence shows how many pounds of grapes Ramon bought in all?

SubTopics: Compare two decimals to hundredths using the symbols >, =, or <, and justify the conclusions.
Content: Which statement correctly compares 10.26 and 10.35?

Key.Rationale: Adds the numbers after the decimal together to establish their values.

B.Choice: Since the whole numbers are the same, 10.26 = 10.35.

Key.Rationale: Compares the whole values correctly, but stops there.

C.Choice: Since the 2 in the tenths place is less than 3, 10.26 < 10.35.

D.Choice: Since the 6 in the hundredths place is greater than 5, 10.26 > 10.35.

Key.Rationale: Compares the decimal values from right to left instead of left to right.

SubTopics: Interpret a multiplication equation as a comparison, e.g., interpret 35 = 5 × 7 as a statement that 35 is 5 times as many as 7 and 7 times as many as 5. Represent verbal statements of multiplicative comparisons as multiplication equations.
Content: Leo and Rachel have boxes of chalk.

:box:• Leo has 6 boxes with 8 pieces in each box.

• Rachel has 8 boxes with 6 pieces in each box.
Which number sentence correctly shows the relationship between the total number of pieces of chalk in Leo's and Rachel's boxes?

Key.Rationale: Chooses the inequality sign based on the first number in each addition expression.
Chooses the inequality sign based on the first number in each multiplication expression.

SubTopics: Multiply or divide to solve word problems involving multiplicative comparison, e.g., by using drawings and equations with a symbol for the unknown number to represent the problem, distinguishing multiplicative comparison from additive comparison.
Recognize, describe, extend, create, and replicate a variety of patterns.
Content: Claire writes a number pattern that starts with 5 and follows the rule “multiply by 2.” Meg writes another number pattern. The fourth number in Meg's pattern is 6 times as large as the fourth number in Claire's pattern. Which expression is equal to the fourth number in Meg's pattern?

Key.Rationale: Starts with 5 and multiplies by 2, so thinks patterns are the 10s (5, 10, 20, 30, ...) and then adds instead of multiplies.
tarts with 5 and multiplies by 2, so thinks patterns are the 10s (5, 10, 20, 30, ...).

SubTopics: Solve multi-step word problems posed with whole numbers using the four operations. Answers will be either whole numbers or have remainders that must be interpreted yielding a final answer that is a whole number. Represent these problems using equations with a symbol or letter standing for the unknown quantity.
Content: Peter, Ingrid, and Anna collect posters. Peter has 14 posters. Ingrid has 6 more posters than Peter. Anna has 3 times as many posters as Ingrid. How many posters do Peter, Ingrid, and Anna have altogether?

Key.Rationale: Uses 8 posters (14 - 6) for Ingrid and 24 posters (3 × 8) for Anna.
Uses 42 posters (3 × 14) for Anna and 48 posters (42 + 6) for Ingrid.

SubTopics: Solve multi-step word problems posed with whole numbers using the four operations. Answers will be either whole numbers or have remainders that must be interpreted yielding a final answer that is a whole number. Represent these problems using equations with a symbol or letter standing for the unknown quantity.
Content: Omar has 25 books. Nan has 3 times as many books as Omar. Nan stores her books in boxes that hold 6 books each. She fills as many boxes as she can and puts the remaining books on a shelf. How many books does Nan put on the shelf?

Key.Rationale: Divides 28 by 6 (thinks Nan has 3 more books than Omar).
Interprets the 5 in 12.5 as 5 remaining books.

SubTopics: Solve multi-step word problems posed with whole numbers using the four operations. Answers will be either whole numbers or have remainders that must be interpreted yielding a final answer that is a whole number. Represent these problems using equations with a symbol or letter standing for the unknown quantity.

Interpret a multiplication equation as a comparison, e.g., interpret 35 = 5 × 7 as a statement that 35 is 5 times as many as 7 and 7 times as many as 5. Represent verbal statements of multiplicative comparisons as multiplication equations.
Content: On vacation, Lou took p photographs. He used 4 times as many memory cards as Kathy. Kathy used 2 memory cards and each card contained 240 photographs. Which equation shows how many photographs (p) Lou took while on vacation?

Key.Rationale: Interprets “4 times as many” as “4 +” AND switches Lou's amount with Kathy's amount.
Switches Lou's amount with Kathy's amount.

SubTopics: Identify the missing symbol (+, -, ×, ÷, =, <, and >) that makes a number sentence true (single-digit divisor only).
Content: Mr. Jones has 50 paintbrushes to give to each of his two art classes.

:box:• His first class has 7 students.

• His second class has 9 students.

During class, Mr. Jones gives each student the same number of paintbrushes. He gives out as many paintbrushes as possible. He then writes the statement shown below to compare the number of paintbrushes he has remaining from each class.
number remaining from the first class [_] number remaining from the second class
What symbol should go into the [_] to make the comparison true?

Key.Rationale: Uses the inequality sign to point to the larger number OR thinks 50-7 > 50-9.
Thinks Mr. Jones will have 0 brushes left from each class, not noticing that neither 7 nor 9 goes into 50 evenly.
Division is used in the problem but not for the comparison.

SubTopics: Find all factor pairs for a whole number in the range 1-100. Recognize that a whole number is a multiple of each of its factors. Determine whether a given whole number in the range 1-100 is a multiple of a given one-digit number. Determine whether a given whole number in the range 1-100 is prime or composite.
Content: How many numbers are both multiples of 4 and factors of 36?

Key.Rationale: Thinks numbers cannot be both multiples and factors of different values.
Thinks only 4 and 36 fit the criteria.

SubTopics: Recognize, describe, extend, create, and replicate a variety of patterns.
Content: Paula starts making a pattern by drawing the shapes shown below.
problems/PA15G4M/media/27a.jpg
The pattern continues. How many sides will Shape 20 have?

Key.Rationale: Thinks the number of sides is equal to the shape number.

SubTopics: Determine the missing elements in a function table (limit to +, -, or × and to whole numbers or money).
Content: Jarod keeps his coin collection in a coin book. The table below shows the total number of coins he has stored based on the number of pages with coins.
problems/PA15G4M/media/28a.jpg
How many coins does Jarod store on each page of the book?

Key.Rationale: First number in the “Number of Coins” column.

SubTopics: Determine the missing elements in a function table (limit to +, -, or × and to whole numbers or money).
Determine the rule for a function given a table (limit to +, -, or × and to whole numbers).
Content: Mrs. Lawson plants the same number of flowers in her garden each week. The table below shows the total number of flowers in her garden at the end of weeks 2, 3, and 4.
problems/PA15G4M/media/29a.jpg
The pattern continues. Which number sentence could be used to find the number of flowers in Mrs. Lawson's garden at the end of week 5?

Key.Rationale: Recognizes a pattern (add 4) but adds it to Week.

SubTopics: Determine the rule for a function given a table (limit to +, -, or × and to whole numbers).
Content: The cost for Akito to call his aunt in Japan is shown in the table below.
problems/PA15G4M/media/30a.jpg
Which pair of equations show two different ways Akito could find the cost to call his aunt for 5 minutes?

Key.Rationale: Thinks the amount doubles each time, just looking at the first two values in the table.
Thinks the previous cost should be added to the number of minutes (and then comes up with a multiplication equation to match).
Thinks the previous cost should be multiplied by 5 (and then comes up with an addition equation to match).

SubTopics: Draw and identify lines and angles, and classify shapes by properties of their lines and angles.
Content: Marisa is using the right triangle, rectangle, rhombus, and square shown below for an art project.
problems/PA15G4M/media/31a.jpg
Marisa cuts one of the shapes along a line of symmetry to form two new shapes. The two new shapes can be identified by the same shape name as the shape that was cut. Which shape did Marisa cut?

Key.Rationale: Line of symmetry would form 2 triangles.
Line of symmetry would form 2 rectangles or 2 triangles.

SubTopics: List properties, classify, draw, and identify geometric figures in two dimensions.
Content: The top of Ricky's kitchen table has exactly one pair of parallel sides. Which figure could be the shape of the top of Ricky's kitchen table?

SubTopics: Classify two-dimensional figures based on the presence or absence of parallel or perpendicular lines, or the presence or absence of angles of a specified size. Recognize right triangles as a category, and identify right triangles.
Content: A company chooses a shape for its new logo. The shape has only obtuse angles and exactly three sets of parallel line segments. Which shape could be the new logo?

Key.Rationale: Can contain only obtuse angles but not three sets of parallel line segments.
Contains no obtuse angles and only two sets of parallel line segments.
Contains one obtuse angle at most and no parallel line segments.

SubTopics: Draw points, lines, line segments, rays, angles (right, acute, obtuse), and perpendicular and parallel lines. Identify these in two-dimensional figures.

Recognize a line of symmetry for a two-dimensional figure as a line across the figure such that the figure can be folded along the line into matching parts. Identify line-symmetric figures and draw lines of symmetry.
Content: Jeremy has a gameboard which folds along a line of symmetry that is perpendicular to one side of the board. Which figure could be Jeremy's gameboard with its line of symmetry?

Key.Rationale: Line of symmetry, but not perpendicular.
Perpendicular, but not a line of symmetry.
Line of symmetry, but not perpendicular.

SubTopics: Classify two-dimensional figures based on the presence or absence of parallel or perpendicular lines, or the presence or absence of angles of a specified size. Recognize right triangles as a category, and identify right triangles.
Draw points, lines, line segments, rays, angles (right, acute, obtuse), and perpendicular and parallel lines. Identify these in two-dimensional figures.
Content: A triangular store display is built from three pieces of wood. Exactly two of the pieces of wood are the same size, and the angle formed by these two pieces of wood is an obtuse angle. Which picture could be the shape of the triangular display?

Key.Rationale: Obtuse angle, but no congruent sides.
Exactly two congruent sides, but no obtuse angles.
Three congruent sides, and no obtuse angles.

SubTopics: Recognize a line of symmetry for a two-dimensional figure as a line across the figure such that the figure can be folded along the line into matching parts. Identify line-symmetric figures and draw lines of symmetry.
Draw points, lines, line segments, rays, angles (right, acute, obtuse), and perpendicular and parallel lines. Identify these in two-dimensional figures.
Content: Which shape has both a line of symmetry and an obtuse angle?

Key.Rationale: Has a line of symmetry, but no obtuse angles.
Has obtuse angle, but no line of symmetry.
Has obtuse angle, but no line of symmetry.

SubTopics: Solve problems involving measurement and conversion of measurements from a larger unit to a smaller unit.
Content: Jason bought a rectangular canvas and a square canvas with the same perimeter. The rectangular canvas is shown below.
problems/PA15G4M/media/37a.jpg
What is the length, in feet, of one side of the square canvas?

Key.Rationale: Length, in yards, of one side of square canvas.
Adds only 3 and 9 to get perimeter of 12.
Length, in feet, of longer side of rectangular canvas.

SubTopics: Use the four operations to solve word problems involving distances, intervals of time, liquid volumes, masses of objects, and money, including problems involving simple fractions or decimals, and problems that require expressing measurements given in a larger unit in terms of a smaller unit. Represent measurement quantities using diagrams such as number line diagrams that feature a measurement scale.
Content: Mikail rode her bike 1 3/4 miles from her school to the park. She then rode her bike 2 3/4 miles from the park to her home. What is the total distance Mikail rode her bike from her school, to the park, and to her home?

Key.Rationale: Converts the fraction 6/4 as 1 2/4, but does not regroup the 1.

SubTopics: Identify time (analog or digital) as the amount of minutes before or after the hour.

Use the four operations to solve word problems involving distances, intervals of time, liquid volumes, masses of objects, and money, including problems involving simple fractions or decimals, and problems that require expressing measurements given in a larger unit in terms of a smaller unit. Represent measurement quantities using diagrams such as number line diagrams that feature a measurement scale.
Content: Lucy started knitting a scarf at a quarter to 5. She finished knitting the scarf at 10 minutes after 7. How many minutes did it take Lucy to knit the scarf?

SubTopics: Organize, display, and answer questions based on data.
Multiply a whole number by a unit fraction (denominators limited to 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, 12, and 100 and final answers do not need to be simplified or written as a mixed number).
Content: The students in Ms. Padah's class have different ways of getting to school, as listed below.

:box:• 12 students get to school by bus.

• 1/2 as many students get to school by car as by bus.

• 1/2 as many students get to school by bike as by car.

• 5 students get to school by walking.
Which data display correctly represents the different ways Ms. Padah's students get to school?

Key.Rationale: Reverses the numbers for riding in a car and biking.
Forgets to divide by 2 for biking and does not use the key for walking to school.
Does not interpret the key correctly for walking.

SubTopics: Solve problems involving addition and subtraction of fractions by using information presented in line plots (line plots must be labeled with common denominators, such as 1/4, 2/4, 3/4).
Content: Ellie is sorting books based on their thickness in inches. She makes a bar graph to show the number of books she has of each thickness.
problems/PA15G4M/media/41a.jpg
Ellie stacks all of the books on top of one another. How thick is Ellie's stack of books?

Key.Rationale: Adds one of each different thickness.
Forgets to include the three 1-inch books.
Counts the total number of books.

SubTopics: Make a line plot to display a data set of measurements in fractions of a unit (e.g., intervals of 1/2, 1/4, or 1/8).
Recognize and generate equivalent fractions.
Content: In the time it took Gia to run a mile, five other runners had run the distances, in miles, shown below.
Which line plot shows the distances, in miles, the other five runners had run?

Key.Rationale: Includes just one x for each unique value.
Correctly converts 1/2 to 4/8 but incorrectly converts 3/4 to 3/8.

SubTopics: Geometric measurement: understand concepts of angle; measure and create angles.
Content: Craig draws two angles. The smaller angle is an acute angle, and the larger angle is an obtuse angle. The measure of the smaller angle is 10° less than the measure of the larger angle. Both angle measures are whole numbers of degrees. What is the greatest possible measure of the larger angle?

Key.Rationale: Greatest possible measure of the smaller angle.
Least possible measure of the larger angle.

SubTopics: Use appropriate tools and units to sketch an angle and determine angle measurements.
Content: At 11:00, the hands of a clock form a 30° angle.
problems/PA15G4M/media/44a.jpg
What is the measure of the angle formed by the clock hands at 8:00?

Key.Rationale: Angle formed by hands pointing to 8 and 11.

SubTopics: Solve addition and subtraction problems to find unknown angles on a diagram in real-world and mathematical problems. (Angles must be adjacent and non-overlapping.)
Content: Three cables holding up a pole are shown below.
problems/PA15G4M/media/45a.jpg
The angle between cable SQ and cable SR is 25°. The angle between cable SP and cable SR is 65°. What is the measure of the angle between cable SP and cable SQ?

Key.Rationale: Assumes both smaller angles are congruent.
Answers by appearance, noting that the larger angle is only slightly larger than QSR.
Adds the two angle measures together.

SubTopics: Use operations to solve problems.
Content: A school district is ordering supplies for each of the 8 schools in the district.
The school district orders a case of pencils for each of the 8 schools. Each case contains 1,325 pencils.
How many pencils does the school district order in all?
The school district also orders 2,432 notebooks. They plan to distribute the notebooks equally to each of the 8 schoosl.
How many notebooks should each of the 8 schools receive?

The school district has 45 folders remaining from last school year. The school district will distribute the same number of folders to each of the 8 schools but does not want any extra folders remaining. If necessary, the school district can purchase more folders so each school receives the same number of folders. New folders are purchased in boxes. There are 15 folders in each box.

Explain why the school district will need to order more boxes of folders. As part of your explanation, determine the LEAST number of boxes the school district can order so each of the 8 schools receives the same number of folders.

SubTopics: Solve problems involving fractions and whole numbers (straight computation or word problems).
Content: Paige measures and records how much her dog eats and drinks.
Paige adds 1/8 quart of water to her dog's water bowl. The bowl already had water in it. After Paige is done pouring water into the bowl, the total amount of water in the bowl is 7/8 quart of water.
What fraction of a quart of water was in the bowl before Paige added water to it?

Paige feeds her dog 1/4 cup of food at each meal. She decides to change to a new kind of dog food. For her dog to get the same amount of nutrition from the new dog food as the old dog food, Paige needs to feed her dog 1/3 cup of the new dog food at each meal.
Paige is feeding her dog more food now than before. Show or explain why this is true.

Paige gets a second dog. At each meal, the new dog needs to eat 2 times more food than her first dog. She knows her first dog eats 1/3 cup of food at each meal. Paige claims that her new dog needs to eat 2/6 cup of food at each meal since 1/3 × 2 = (1 × 2)/(3 × 2) = 2/6.
Explain the mistake Paige made when calculating the amount of food the new dog needs to eat at each meal. As part of your answer, state how much food the new dog should actually eat at each meal.

SubTopics: Use numbers and symbols to model the concepts of expressions and equations.
Content: Joanie is counting her art supplies.
She has 32 bottles of paint. That is 4 times the number of paint brushes she has.
How many paint brushes does Joanie have?
Joanie has a total of 44 markers. She has 1 pack that has 16 markers in it. She has 2 packs that each have m markers.
Write a number sentence that can be used to find m.
Joanie has 127 crayons. She equally divides as many of her crayons as possible into 8 boxes.
What is the GREATEST number of crayons Joanie can put into each box? Show or explain all your work.
Joanie wants to fill 3 more boxes with the same number of crayons as determined in Part C.
How many more crayons does Joanie need? Show or explain all your work

SubTopics: List properties, classify, draw, and identify geometric figures in two dimensions.
Content: A square flag is shown below.
On the flag shown below, draw two lines of symmetry that are perpendicular to each other.
problems/PA15G4M/media/49a.jpg
Explain how someone could know that the lines you drew in Part A are lines of symmetry.
Explain how someone could know that the lines you drew in Part A are perpendicular to each other.
Explain why it is NOT possible to draw two different lines of symmetry that are parallel to each other.

SubTopics: Use appropriate tools and units to sketch an angle and determine angle measurements.
Content: Every day, Liban walks the same route to school.
The diagram below shows a part of the route he walks.
problems/PA15G4M/media/50a.jpg
Using your protractor, what is the measure of the angle, in degrees, created by First Street and Third Avenue?
As Liban continues his route, Third Avenue meets School Lane. The angle created by Third Avenue and School Lane is 115°.
Using your protractor and the line segment shown below, draw the angle created by Third Avenue and School Lane.
On Friday, Liban walked to the park after school. When he looked at the playground, he noticed many different angles, including the ones shown below.
problems/PA15G4M/media/50b.jpg
Combined, the three angles have a measure of 180°. Liban tried to find the measure of the middle angle using the work shown below.
Liban's answer is not correct.
Explain the error Liban made.
What is the measure, in degrees, of the middle angle?
